review_title: Not good: Nokia Tech in Sunnyvale
pros: Good salary, friendly team, nice office that is close to Caltrain.  Pretty flexible work environment in regards to time off, etc.  Smart teammates.
cons: No clear direction of the company.  Awful leadership.  Acquisition of Withings has been a disaster that led to a year's worth of hard work being scrapped.  Part of a big company, but none of the benefits of that (HR is a joke, e.g., benefits enrollment was done on a piece of paper).

- Never dread Mondays anymore.
cons: It's a busy environment and can get a little rowdy but nothing some headphones can't solve.

review_title: Nokia Alfragide - Bad start for your career
pros:
- Take you time to learn on your own pace. You'll only  start to do prevention 24x7  if you feel OK to it. 
- International environment where you meet and talk with people from everywhere in the world. 
- very good salary for first job, but you can't expect that it will change in the future as much you work hard
- the open space building is very nice 
- low volume of work to do. It could be a bad thing since you won't be pushed and won't feel pressed to learn more.
- you get a parking lot place after a year or so after you start working here, since a lot of people leave the job after 2-4 years.
- Canteen with a good variety in the menu: Vegetarian, Mediterranean food, stakes, fish,  deserts, fruits, soups and a bar. In the NOC/GDC building a bar with coffee machines, chocolate and sandwich machines, microwaves, tables if you want to bring food from home.
- Equality in the job. You see people of all races, gender and ages. Good culture and values.
- Flexible work time
cons:
- Your first job after you conclude your Degree will define your future, and working for  Nokia-Alfragide will bury it. This company is only for starters that couldn't find another opportunity.
- The knowledge gained here is very low and no other telecom company will hire you because you worked for Nokia. Remember you are the first line of support, so they don't expect that you gain deep knowledge.
- They hire people from high schools and technicians with no degree to do the same job as you do, that took for you 3 or 5 years  to take, so they won't give you any value or advantage to have one degree.
- This GDC/NOC is intended to be a first line of support like a call center or help desk, so they don't give you advanced training, superficial training only.
- There are no career advance, you'll earn always the same thing.
- The lab is very poor,  most of times the only contact with the network elements will be remotely at customer's equipment.
- Most of the technologies you work here are phased-out, so the knowledge you learn here will be trowed to the trash soon.
- Due to the constant restructure and fusion and divorce (Nokia Siemens Networks, Nokia Solutions Networks, Nokia Networks, Nokia-Alcatel) this company is a mess 
- The line managers are so much incompetent and do nothing. In most of the teams there aren't team meetings or audits, so no feedback on your work and you are by your own here . 
- Here you are a number and don't feel that you have a value to the company.
- Don't expect any help from teammates since they also don't know anything or don't want to tell and you'll have to rely on higher layers of support (from other countries) in the standard process of support.
-  slow computers that kills your performance
-  your eyes will suffer if your desk is near a window or in a place with poor illumination
- no compensation, no benefits.   You work at night in the prevention and you aren't payed, they tell you to take a rest at the day.

pros: If you are fortunate to have good line manager then things are good. you will have good growth and better learning.
cons:
Mostly teams stationed in India are headed by process heads sitting in Finland or Budapest. Workforce at lower and middle management are stationed in India. this is 70% of workforce. Senior and top management are located in Finland and Budapest. You will experience complete difference on the basis of geography. A per son much junior to you and being european will grow like anything and in 5 years he will be 3 level , vertically promoted. this is Nokias culture. Finnish management though good, still cannnot control this and trust europeans only. When you will talk about your growth , you being in India will be told about policies. Multiple times, teams in india are not given any increments. But if you are a european you will be given promotions every year and you will find yourself reporting to a line manager, who is basically much junior, but has grown on the basis of geography. However if they target you all false compliance cases will be created against you and you though being rated as top manager by your team, still you will be humiliated by India HR and senior managers sitting in Budapest. HR india is puppet of europeans, they have only one policy, to follow instructions received from europe. You will get all kind of pressures. there is clear discrimination between Europeans and asians , particulary India.  
they will talk about values infact  They have arrogant senior management in budapest.

review_title: Bad experience . Relaxed life. No career growth
pros:
1. Big brand name in telco domain . 
2. Many wfh 
3. No work . One can simply come to office , then play tt .. and go home.
4. One can come at 10 and leave by 6 .
cons:
Everything ...
1. As i have mentioned there is no work, so growth is not there.
2. Too much politics ..
3.  From a developer point of view very very less opportunity to learn anything . 
4. Although they say that they have the policy of internal job switching  but it depends on the manager and his manager, whether you will be released or not . They will threaten people who over tries to switch internal saying.. it will get blocked from higher management. So now u have come to bad book higher management ..etc... 

So ultimately people leave ..
5. Micro management at its peak level.
6.  Rather than doing any actual work, they will spend time for just unnecessary , redundant Meeting and meetings.. and for which delivery gets delayed. when the delivery date comes, if u raise these concerns, they will simply refuse. 

7. DON'T join specially if you are developer. U will join as developer.. then u will do testing work .. 
As there is not much work.. maximum time u will do testing only.. 
8. Salary is avg . Less than other product companies.. they will give around 12lpa for 7 exp. 
If are lateral joining with higher package. Next 2 years u will not get hike.


But yeah.. if you want relaxed life.. no work. No career growth. With a decent salary , come to office at 10 and leave by 6 then it is good for u.. that is the reason in Glassdoor every review has that "work life balance" .. 

Think twice before joining this company. Don't join Just because of brand name..It's your career .

review_title: saving more more important than making it
job_title: Solutions Architect in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros: cannot think of any. would rather be unemployed than work for nokia.
cons:
I worked for Nokia years ago, was transferred to another software company who then fired everyone in my team. I got a job with Comptel and sadly Nokia bought Comptel, ruined the company and many people (including me) left soon after but Nokia started firing many people as well. 
When I got fired first time around thanks to Nokia outsourcing I didn't even look at what jobs Nokia was offering .. so basically I would rather have been unemployed than work for Nokia again. 
Nokia is an awful place to work, the company focusses on huge network deals to operators so quality of the products and employing good people is not important. People are relentlessly and regularly fired from "high cost" countries in western Europe and jobs move to india/china/eastern Europe. They did this when I worked there first time around and started doing it again with Comptel products but happily I'm not staying around to see what else happens at Nokia Finland.  You only have to look at the drop in numbers in Finland where it's now only 6000 employees and they're firing another 350 in early 2019. 
I do not know one person in Comptel who says the purchase by Nokia has been a good thing, one of my other colleagues who left wrote in linked in that the company has a culture where saving money is more important than making it, which totally sums up the Nokia culture. It was horrible to work in a company with that attitude and I'm so glad to have left that behind. There are not even people at HR to contact (even when resigning), you use one (of the dozens) of tools they have at Nokia to submit enquiries even to HR. They were even launching a HR chatbot so that your reply would not come from a real person. This state of affairs meant that my resignation request wasn't processed for about 10 days thanks to endless tools and no HR to actually talk to.

review_title: So many wrong things with this company
pros: Somewhat of a pro: compensation package (eyeglasses/dental, transportation/bike, childbirth - one gross salary, kindergarten, and some other minor expense reimbursements)
cons:
- Plain bad management: managers get promoted from 'inside' based on seniority, not merit or skills. you have to wait 10 years for some other manager to leave or to die to have a chance at being promoted.
       - they don't foster a trusting environment for the employees and ask for weekly written reports even for seniors with 10+ years experience even though all activity is already tracked in Jira
      - they don't allow home office even though company policy is 1-2 days/week.

- Questionable upper management:
      Mr. Tommi Uitto has some very dubious and questionable initiatives: promoting gender equality by promoting more women in management positions (this is obviously not bad, but promoting women solely on their gender is...); Also he's comparing work conditions in Nokia with Huawei where people work 6 days/week and sometimes sleep in the office only to conclude how good it is at Nokia where (some) people are able to work from home 2 days/week. He also used this (and the fact that being together physically as a team will foster better communication) as a basis to cut those two days to one and eventually to 0 (as opposed to more and more companies who figured out the opposite and start implementing full remote work).
       It's really obvious that management doesn't really care about people.

- The technical level of employees is very low. Of course, there are very good people too, but most of them are leaving and juniors are taking their place. 

- Substandard workspace: huge overcrowded open offices of >120 persons, very noisy
       very very cold in winter
       after heavy rain outside you get pools of water randomly all over the office
       crap coffee
       no fruits or absolutely anything company sponsored
       restrooms are incredibly dirty, especially in office H
       everything is cost-saving oriented, starting with lack of dishwasher soap and paper towels

In conclusion, I have no idea how such a badly managed company still exists. Probably thanks to Trump's ban on Huawei and Chinese vendors...

review_title: Nokia of America Corp. is actively downsizing R&D locations in USA
pros: Most competent technical people and excellent company benefits
cons: R&D locations in USA are targeted for ongoing downsizing in order to transfer functions to low-cost centers in Europe and China.  Job security is very tenuous.

review_title: Don't waste your time, go somewhere else. A very toxic culture.
pros: Some of the peoples / engineers are very skilled ones, unfortunately not many are left, but a lot to learn from those individuals.
cons:
There was a great Nokia culture and spirit till the Siemens merger (2007), once that happened, a very hierarchical organisation and culture was implemented. It took years to turn the culture around, still very far from the old Nokia culture and values (ex. Customer Satisfaction, Respect for the individual, Achievement, Continuous learning). 

Then Nokia purchased back the Siemens stake (2013) so became the only owner of the whole company. That turned out as a great move. Somehow Nokia culture came back and in two years reached the same level as it was in the 90s with tremendous success, clear vision, great execution, openness, direction, but did not last as in 2015, Nokia purchased Alu. That turned all upside-down.

Basically the culture that came with the acquisition also thrived. Unfortunately it was the one of lying, cheating, secrecy and so on as most of the leadership team came from Alu or outside Nokia. In other words, Alu purchased Nokia with Nokia money as none of the Nokia values where preserved. Fast forward 5 years later, to 2020 and here is the result:

- Management by fear with "know it all" attitude. Problems, opinions or arguments of any kind, even well documented are not accepted, moreover are punished.
- "Fake it till you make it" is the name of the game. Winer is the one that lie, cheat, fake as much as possible. When caught, even by the internal ethics committee, they are not punished, but moreover, they are most of them promoted.
- Management does not trust or even bothered to listen to experts and engineers, as a result, peoples does not trust management. Very vicious circle, hard to break especially that top management is surrounded by lieutenants that only execute blindly the orders.
- Promotion and encouragement of total secrecy and fierce internal competition making peoples and teams to hate each other, fight for their life basically. No sharing of info. A lot of duplicate work just because of the "not made here" disease. As a result, best solutions never win.
- Pure politically driven decisions against the Nokia overall health. No corporate global long term vison. No alignment between business units of any kind.
- Management totally disconnected and blinded by their own political agendas. It seems that they are in a closed loop not accepting any input that is not aligned or does not confirm their personal views.
- Continuous layoffs (at least once a year in last 10 years) based on random decisions, very much accelerated after the Alu acquisition. In other words, does not matter what you do, how you do, how you perform. If you are in the wrong place, in the wrong time, you are out. It happened that for a certain project, best of the best where gathered to make it happened and one year later, all fired when project was ditched.
- Continuous internal reorganisations (up to 4-5 reorganisations only in 2019), basically breaking teams, breaking network, breaking all connections, very hard to accomplish anything. No explanations, no justification. 
Changes just for the sake of changes.
- Peoples wellbeing is only on paper: filthy offices, very noisy open spaces, zero facilities for any activities except some ridiculous gyms in very bad locations, ethical office is just show off as does not have in practice any effect, compensation below industry average.

review_title: great company working hard in tough market and technology

cons: Management heavy with lots of old timers and politics of survival and growth.

review_title: Working culture and environment needs vast improvement
pros:
Great learning experience, knowledge sharing, and employee benefits.
Many opportunities to work in projects.
cons:
Dull, strict working environment and office politics.
Lack of interaction and inclusion among employees.
Highly political and back-biting culture.
Even though one of the values is respect, sadly it is not practiced here.
Lack of career advancement and progression opportunities.

review_title: Great people, too many management layers and matrixes
pros:
International culture
Colleagues 
Creating the future
Enthusiastic people
Professional colleagues 
If you have the right drive and competence you can go a long way in Nokia.
cons:
Too many levels of management make it impoiisble to take decisions. 
Internal processess and procedures are a nightmare and makes it impossible to be productive at work. 

Uncertainty for employees; new changes and transformations every year.

review_title: A humanized company with great culture
pros: A great humanized company having over 150 years culture,  in which you can work under harmonious atmosphere and get growth  by learning everyday, to make work and life balanced always.
cons: "willing to take" mindset need to be improved during project implementation, since too  harmony is not so good to burst new idea for high technology company.

pros: Nokia is great company in the world, it has more than 150 years history and looking forward to see Nokia's bright future and long life in the world.
cons: I think it is OK and I am still enjoy my work and life in Nokia now a ways.

pros:
If you get the correct role, you will enjoy the work you do here 
All the colleagues are friendly
Work/Life balance is great
cons:
Pays below the market
Do not expect high rise after you join,so do your best negotiation when you first join

review_title: This is not my Nokia anymore
pros: Home Office Connection. Work remotely help employer to balance better work and private life time.
cons: 12 years of continuous reduction of staff have destroyed internal democracy, every policy of merit and demotivated most of the few survivors.

pros: Relaxed work environment. No one is on you as long as you get your stuff done. Which isn't much to ask.
cons: Management don't are not competent. Job role is usually not clear and you basically figure it out as you go. Few smart people due to attrition. Below average compensation

pros: Good Managers in some departments and enough free time out of your work if you can do it quick and efficiently. Once your work is done no will ask for you like other companies.
cons: Career growth is slow and lot of re organisation every time which will scare you

review_title: Respect, Growth, Leadership. Most satisfying choice
pros: Respect, Growth, Leadership. You can get them all in Nokia. Thoughtful working environment, great teams and wonderful balance between work and life.
cons: If you have any thing in your mind, just do it, It's an open platform for you. Colleagues are happy to give you a hand at any time. Hence you don't need to worry about making mistake.

pros: world known company, great  people, most of the time nice work environment
cons:
Nokia keeps restructuring, you always have to face changes and adapt yourself to new strategies and new management!
It seems as well that Nokia is always one train late on new innovations

review_title: A nice place but technologically backwards manager

Amazing code architecture.
Too much to learn
Nice top level managers/decision makers

review_title: good place to work, flat org strucuture

quality of middle level managers not so good, 
sales evry operational role...won't learn too much of marketing
too much of reporting which eats into your time for field work

review_title: a company without a clear vision and great leader

cons: To many employee that join with this company, so small opportunity for grow and get more career on the future.

pros: Can learn much and make some good friends. People have good relationship and can help each others.  It's happy to working there.

review_title: Great work environment but not good to start a career

Can work in any Field as long as your manager approves.

Too many processes coming in the way of each other.

People create work only to justify their presence leading to unnecessary issues

pros: Strong global experience and brand recognition for the parent companies.  The company started with very smart people but because of the issues, many of them left.
cons: Difficult to get your job done, as everything had to go to Finland for approval.  Promotions were based on internal politics and not results.

review_title: Very nice colleagues and a multicultural environment

cons: There weren't enough career opportunities for non-engineers. I felt that my learning potential was not appreciated - I was expected to stay put in my (then) current position as that was what I was good at.

pros: Always can find interesting project to work on. Family friendly workplace. Respect for various cultures. Travel opportunities for the interested. Trainings are possible even in economically har times.
cons: Salary is not the best. Slow decision making, not enough innovation. Business outlook is not the best, asian copetition is coming close. Hopefully they will make a good deal in LTE business.

pros: Good market position as #2 supplier in telecom infrastructure equipment.
cons: This is a joint venture company between the cellular infrastructure divisions from Nokia and Siemens. They are still trying to find their way in melding the 2 companies together. They need to get better processes in place and improve quality.

review_title: Its been like being part of a business school study
pros: When things were great this was the best place to work in...flat organization, no primadonnas and everyone  pulling in the same direction in a real team effort
cons: When  things got tough, the good people left and a bunch of not so good people were left managing the sinking ship. Will it survive...who knows!

review_title: Used to be very good Technology Company..............

Your manager is your god. He is the one who will make or break your future in NSN. No accountability of Line/Resource Managers. 
It is a company focussed on Managers. No value of skills. There EES are fake and Ethics are low. Probably worst in North America.

pros: Working hours are ok, no need to do a lot of overtime. Atmosphere among employees is good. There is flexibility and you are valued as a colleague if you accomplish things

pros: Gave me multiple Opportunities to learn new technologies and trends. Learning was emphasized and encouraged. Exposure to global teams. Great benefits for the US employees.

pros: Recognizable name. Great exposure.

pros: Gain experience with multiple platforms and internal training. Communicate with many customers around the world and get different insights.
